href="http://nottingham.ac.uk/Biosciences/business/business.aspx?SyndicationType=2" rel="self" type="application/atom+xml" />   <entry>     <title>CASCADE-FELLOWS Marie Curie Fellowships in Life Sciences</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/biosciences/news/2015-cascade-fellows-marie-curie-fellowships-in-life-sciences.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Qingqi Wang</name>     </author>     <summary>There is an EU scheme "CASCADE fellowships" that may be of interest as a way of attracting excellent non-UK postdoctoral researchers and also to make money go further/provide additional funding.</summary>     <published>2015-02-17T14:59:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-02-17T14:40:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/biosciences/news/2015-cascade-fellows-marie-curie-fellowships-in-life-sciences.aspx</id>     <category term="Fellowship" />     <category term="funding" />     <category term="biosciences" />     <category term="postdoctoral" />   </entry>   <entry>     <title>New tools to breed cereal crops that survive flooding</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/news/pressreleases/2015/february/new-tools-to-breed-crops-that-survive-flooding.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Qingqi Wang</name>     </author>     <summary>Scientists at The University of Nottingham hope new research could lead to the introduction of cereal crops better able to tolerate flooding. They have identified the mechanism used by plants in stress conditions to sense low oxygen levels and used advanced breeding techniques to reduce yield loss in barley in water-logged conditions. Read more ...</summary>     <published>2015-02-12T11:04:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-02-12T11:00:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/news/pressreleases/2015/february/new-tools-to-breed-crops-that-survive-flooding.aspx</id>     <category term="Crops" />     <category term="biosciences" />     <category term="Research" />     <category term="cereal" />   </entry> </feed>
